segments.text: The people in the boondocks, they didn't know what to believe.
The VC come in, if they don't do what they tell them, they'll destroy everything.
We come in, we destroy everything.
The civilian population didn't know what to think.
Did you know much about the enemy?
Did you come in contact?

no the only enemy we came in contact with was after after a battle maybe we did very rarely do we wind up with any prisoners so we didn't get first-hand knowledge of the enemy except they were good and the fact that they set up an ambush where they wake you right on top of them before they open fire but it never really met you face to face usually at a distance
The brush is so thick you can't see them.
They can see us.
Hell, we're six foot.
They're a little parched.
They're hugging the ground and we're standing straight up.
They see us.
We don't see them.
Second time, I went to a PW camp one time, but I didn't really talk to the enemy.
They were just as dedicated as we were.
In fact, they were probably more dedicated.
than we were and definitely more dedicated than New Orleans.
Did you find any problems with leadership, drugs, or what's known as fragging?
Not in my youth.
We did not have any trouble of any kind.
In fact, my troops wouldn't know what drugs were
and where would they have gotten it?
We were never in the cities.
We were strictly in the dugouts.
Now, I'm sure that the troops in Saigon and Vung Tau and Cam Ranh Bay and all those large places probably had it.
Just like that movie Apocalypse Now, I thought that was one of the biggest disgraces of the so-called depiction of Vietnam.
If the troops were like that,
In a combat situation, they wouldn't survive.
I understand later in the 70s there was a lot of drug use over there.
I wasn't there in the 70s.
But from my experience, if you have good leadership, the troops respect the leader, they're not going to get involved in that stuff because, hey, they want to go home.
They're not going to go home if they're stoning on a combat operation.
That's just inviting disaster.
As far as leadership goes, well, in the officer ranks in our division, an officer spent six months in the field and then he'd be taken to the rear and put in a staff position someplace.
An enlisted man, he's committed
to the boondocks from the day he got there until the day he leaves.
So your average enlisted man and the noncommissioned officer, they're the ones that are constantly in each other's contact.
And to my knowledge, in our unit, with a very few exceptions, the troops had complete faith in their noncommissioned officer.
They can care less about an officer.
In fact, sometimes I believe the only reason some of these characters become officers is they know they can't make it as an enlisted man.
What did you think about careerism, people trying to get ahead by falsifying body counts?
I have no use for that stuff.
I mean, if you can find a body, fine, you found it.
But don't say there's ten when you don't find one.
Don't falsify any reports, be honest.
I mean, it's the same thing as... You don't need to falsify any kind of information to get advantage.
To get advanced, all you got to do is do your job to the best of your ability.
You don't have to falsify or fake anything.
In fact, I think I'm, I hope I'm a good example of that.
I wound up one of the youngest first sergeants that I ever heard of in the United States Army.
In fact, the average person doesn't make first sergeant until after he's been 18 years.
I only had something like 12 when I became a first sergeant.
And in fact, that turned the sergeant major down so that I could retire, because if I'd accepted what I'd had, it would stay two more years.
But after I finally made staff sergeant, nine months later I became a sergeant in first class.
A year, year and a half later, I became a first sergeant.
I just, to me at the time, I thought I was in the right place at the right time.
But I had a couple commanders told me otherwise.
But we won't rule you that way.
Do you think the methods we used to measure the war were sufficient?
No.
I don't think anything used to measure what took place in Vietnam is even remotely accurate.
Vietnam was a political fiasco.
Soldiers don't declare war.
Soldiers don't start war.
Soldiers are only there to fight war.
The politicians are the ones who make decisions.
We couldn't do anything in Vietnam without some clown
in Washington, D.C., telling us to do it.
It was just a political expediency.
One, I think it was a testing ground for some of our new weapons, what used to be called Cochrane.
At the time, Cochrane was classified.
But half the weapons we used in Vietnam were relatively new.
Never been tried before.
Never tried in Vietnam.
I didn't volunteer to go to Vietnam.
But I went.
Because I was sick.
I thought I went there to fight a war.
And our political ideology is right.
We're trying to contain communism.
But we didn't contain any communism.
All we did was destroy.
It wasn't like World War II.
Everything about World War II was well defined.
On top of that, our philosophy is not to conquer.
We want to win, but then when we win, we don't exploit.
We rebuild.
And as a result, Germany and Japan
are two of the greatest industrial nations in the world today because we helped rebuild after we defeated them.
Vietnam, we abandoned them.
In fact, we abandoned them right after World War II.
During World War II, Ho Chi Minh fought with the American OSS.
against the Japanese.
And because of World War II, the French government had to abandon Vietnam.
Vietnam was a colony of France.
And that colonialism was interrupted briefly during World War II.
And after the war, the Allies abandoned Vietnam
Ho Chi Minh asked for our assistance to prevent the French from coming back and establishing colonialism again.
We didn't even respond to his request.
We just flat ignored him.
And the French come back again with their arrogance and everything and recolonizes the Vietnamese people and Ho Chi Minh
Well, his name wasn't Wu Chi Minh, really, but that's what he became.
And he was constantly asking for assistance.
We want to be a free and independent country.
We don't want to be a lackey of France, this and that.
And the British, they're just exploiting us.
They're taking all the resources out, treating the people like slaves.
So...
the Viet Minh's predator, fighting against France.
And, of course, Ho Chi Minh was the principal leader of the Viet Minh, where the name Minh comes from.
Now, they were doing pretty good.
In fact, just before D&D and Pew, when they quit France, France asked for our assistance to help them out.
And we refused, so France kicked us, our military forces, out of France.
They stayed in NATO, but they kicked us out of France.
We had a pretty bad relationship with France.
But we didn't go in and help the French against the Vietnamese.
We didn't help the Vietnamese against the French, although we were there.
We'd been there ever since World War II.
The average person doesn't know that.
And then all of a sudden, after Vietnam,
after the Indian Peel in 1954, then there was already a North and South Vietnam.
And then the South Vietnamese asked for assistance against the North Vietnamese.
And we had a treaty with them, and so we assist the South Vietnamese against the North Vietnamese.
Here we're fighting an old ally who, if
The politicians that paid attention during World War II, there would not have been such a thing as North and South Vietnam.
There would not have been communism in Vietnam.
It would have been a democracy.
But since we would not assist the Vietnamese back in 46, 47 later, they went to the communists for assistance.
And that's why you have communist regime in Vietnam.
What did you think about what was going on back home with demonstrations and the National Guard?
Well, I don't care for all the demonstrations and whatnot.
In fact, the people in the United States didn't really know what was going on in Vietnam except what they saw on TV.
And TV news and Vietnam was the first war ever broadcast on TV.
But it's one-sided.
And journalists, their function is to sell a story.
They don't go out and get a really true depiction of what's going on.
Now, what they showed on TV was factual, but it was the presentation.
They twist things around.
CBS in particular is good for that.
But that's one thing about being an American.
If you don't agree, you have the right to get up and say something.
And that's one reason why I spent my life in the military.
To protect that freedom.
People are free to voice their opinion.
As long as their opinion doesn't hurt somebody else.
And they can demonstrate all they want.
They can holler at me and say anything they want.
But I know what I did.
They don't know what I did.
They just think they know.
People coming back from World War II, Korea, they came back as heroes.
People coming back from Vietnam, they just spit at you.
But that just won't show ignorance.
They think that we're there killing little babies, and I'm sure we did for the most part.
But most of that is accidental.
I mean, you can't control
mass bombing, or mass artillery strike.
You know there's an enemy there, but those enemies are also going to have other people around them.
So we try not to conduct atrocities.
The National Guard's a good organization.
In fact, half the people in the National Guard are ex-military personnel, active duty.
And they've proven themselves in many wars.
How about selective service?
The draft?
I think the draft is necessary.
There shouldn't be a volunteer military force.
Everybody should devote a little bit of time.
Two years for the draft is sufficient.
Chances of a person having to go to combat are relatively slim.
Military experience is good for anybody.
But one of these days, and I doubt if it's all that far away, there's going to be a war on American soil.
Somebody is going to try to take over the United States.
And fortunately, I don't believe they'll ever win.
The private citizen in the United States has too many weapons.
to let some foreign power come in here and overtake us.
And we're about the only country in the world where the private citizen can have weapons.
Europeans, Asians, it's still legal for them to have anything more than a 12-gauge shotgun.
But Americans are well armed and we intend to keep our freedom
one of these days.
We've been lucky.
There's never been a war fought on our soil since the American Civil War, fortunately.
But with today's weaponry, we can fire it on from hundreds of miles away, and all they need to do is a couple of well-placed rounds, missiles so to speak, in certain areas, and they can come in with
air assault or amphibious and go to town.
They could cripple us in one day before we could respond.
Because everything we have is centrally located pretty much and it's spread out but it's all, for example, you take Houston.
One missile in Pasadena would wipe out Harris County in several

surrounding counties just from one round everything will be spontaneous all of our military bases san antonio has something like four air force bases and an army base all within a small area everything in the united states is well documented well publicized our potential enemy is russia they have all the order of battle they need about us
They can pick up any newspaper, how their satellites fly around, whatnot.
They know where our key areas are.
And I'm sure they have a missile aimed at that particular location.
They even know where our missile silos are.
It's supposed to be top secret.
But we don't know where three-quarters of their stuff is.
They're secretive.
We're too open-minded.
However, nobody is ever going to conquer the United States.
It would be impossible.
They might inflict a hell of a lot of casualties, but then all of a sudden we'd be just like the partisans in Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia during World War II.
In all your movies, they always depict the French partisans, but the French were secondary compared to the Yugoslavs.
and the Czechoslovakians.
They were the true fighters of World War II.
How could we have won the war?
Who do you think is responsible for our holy hell?
And should we have even been there to begin with?
First, I don't think we should have been there unless we went in right after World War II.
If we had gone in right after World War II, we could have set up a sovereign government
just like we did with Germany and Japan.
We were there and done with old French, Britain, and the United States and Germany.
And then in 1955, we returned sovereignty to the German people.
We did it before that in Japan.
We could have done it for Vietnam.
But our politicians sent us there.
So there we were.
If the politicians had kept their nose out of it, if they were going to commit us to fight a war, they should have let us fight it.
The way we know it's supposed to be.
We could have started at one end of that country and swept on through and there wouldn't have been anything there.
Except Reynolds.
We could have driven the unfriendlies out.
No doubt about it.
We had the manpower.
We had the weapons.
And we have the know-how.
But the politicians were the idiots fighting the war.
But they're fighting it several thousand miles away.
Now, if the politicians are going to commit us to a war, we ought to put the politicians in there and let them fight it and see how long it goes.
There probably wouldn't be one to start with.
But they're safe and sound back in Washington, D.C., or
Well, when they do go to a combat zone, they don't get out of Saigon or Cam Ranh Bay.
They don't get to places like Don Tan and Mito and Van Head, Klajurang.
They stay back there where it's relatively safe.
Politicians are exponents of freedom.
We did not lose the war.
We were not allowed to fight the war.
And then as a result, because of the casualties mounting up,
The sentiment back home, they come up with some ploy and they withdraw.
Well, since they did it that way, why did they put us there in the first place?
How do you feel about Vietnam and the conflict today?
Is it any different from before?
I wish we had been able to establish a sovereign nation.
if the North wanted to stay communist, fine.
But I can't really see any one nation trying to inflict its view, its policy, or anything, on another nation.
And we're very bad about that.
We try to, we think we're the only, we're the king of the crop, and we try to inflict our view on everybody else.
Vietnamese people, there's nothing wrong with the people.
They just want to live in a world of peace.
Right now, they're still not in peace.
The communists come in and put their indoctrination in on everything, and those that had something in the past, they don't have any spot now.
And the ones that didn't have anything in the past, they have even less now.
The poorer get poorer.
Same with
The Vietnamese people were abandoned after we told them we were going to help them.
And any of those people that did assist us, when the Communists came in, they were annihilated.
That's why you have so many refugees now, so-called boat people, trying to get away.
That tells the world about Communism.
Even in Europe today, the Berlin Wall.
The Berlin Wall still can't keep everybody in.
Why build a wall to keep people in?
Walls are supposed to keep people out.
That's all.
Thank you very much for allowing me to interview you.
You're welcome.
